results.title: Egg
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Anne Gilhooly and Nicole Mitchell
results.brief_description:
An elderly woman living alone in her suburban family home makes a friend - a fallen bird’s egg she finds in the local park. She takes Egg into her home, and into her heart.
A sensual and evocative film about lonliness, life and love.
Features Paulette Perry as the woman.

results.title: Warriors and dancers
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Narjiic Day-Burns
results.brief_description:
Narjiic’s passion for music and dance began in Year 10 when he was asked to perform for NAIDOC Week. From there he joined various dance groups performing all over Victoria including his home town Echuca, finally enrolling at Swinburne. Today he blends a fusion of traditional dance with hip-hop as a way of expressing his thoughts and emotions. Dance has become a part of his life.
Music by Fonetik.

results.title: Road to Alice
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Frances McGivern and Stavros Kazantzidis
results.brief_description: Jimmy (Noah Taylor) owes Dimitri more money than he can spare. He decides that a holiday would be a better bet. On his travels he meets Louis (Hugo Weaving) and things start to go wrong. Cast also includes Helen Buday, Leone Carmen, Angelo D’Angelo, Emil Minty. Best Short Film, AFI Awards (1992). Original format 16mm/colour.

results.title: Warm strangers
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Melanie Coombs and Ivan Sen
results.brief_description: At the end of his journey, Jess attempts to reunite with his father whom he has not seen for years. Powerful short from the director of ‘Beneath Clouds’ (2002), Produced by Melanie Coombs (‘Harvey Krumpet’). Original format 16mm/black and white.

results.title: Getting wet
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Chris Fitchett and P.J. Hogan
results.brief_description: Fifteen-year-old Alex has always adored Brenda, who has helped his mother around the house for years, but she hardly notices him. When his mother asks Brenda to go on their annual beach holiday to help her out, Alex thinks his chance has come to impress her. But, as usual, it is his older brother Michael who gets the girl. Alex thinks he will never be happy again - until he meets Margaret and his adolescent fantasies come true.

results.title: Flux
results.brief_description:
A film about trust, about an accident, about falling out of love and about emerging from grief. Flux was created entirely on a desktop Macintosh using Adobe AfterEffects and Adobe Photoshop. It was then transferred to 35mm film using a Solitair Film Recorder. It is listed by Lynden Barber (film critic for The Australian newspaper) as one of ‘12 Film Breakthroughs’ for its achievement as the first Australian film post-produced entirely on a home computer.
WARNING: This film contains scenes that may disturb some viewers.

results.title: Joy
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Rachel Clements and Cate Shortland
results.brief_description:
Thursday night. Late night shopping. Joy wants to have fun. This film follows a teenage girl as she hits the town in search of a good time. But Joy’s search for fulfillment leaves her lost and lonely at the end of the evening as we follow her to her unhappy home. By the director of ‘Somersault’ (2004). Original format 35mm/colour.
WARNING: This film contains scenes that may offend some viewers.

results.title: A Girl's own story
results.brief_description:
Set in the Beatlemania of the 1960s, this is a stylised account of girlhood - where perversion is innocent, family is strange and adulthood lonely. From the director of ‘The Piano’ (1993) and ‘In the Cut’ (2003). Original format 16mm/black and white.
WARNING: Some scenes may cause offence to some viewers.

results.title: Peel
results.brief_description: A red-headed family’s drive in the countryside begins an intrigue of awesome belligerence and obstinacy. This short student drama from the director of ‘The Piano’ (2003) was the winner of the Palme d’Or for best short film at Cannes in 1986. Original format 16 mm/colour.

results.title: Caravan park
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Anthony Buckley and Phil Noyce
results.brief_description: When their car breaks down on the way to Queensland, a family is forced to take up residence at a caravan park while the father tries to earn enough money to get the car repaired. Much of the film is seen through the eyes of their young son as he comes to realise some of the complexities of his parents’ relationship. Great realist film from the director of ‘Patriot Games’ (1992), ‘The Bone Collector’ (1999) and ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ (2002). Based on the story by John Emery. Photography by Tom Cowan, editing by Anthony Buckley and production assistant, Gillian Armstrong. Original Format 16mm/black and white.
